translated: Points of Controversy
The Great Fifty🔽The sixteenth section
Discussion of the non-arousing of pleasure
Does one person arouse pleasure in another?
“Yes.”
Does one person arouse pain in another?
“That can’t be said.”

analyzed: paraḥ parassa dukkham na anuppadeti iti
translated: Does one person not arouse pain in another?
“Yes.”

analyzed: paraḥ parassa sukham na anuppadeti iti
translated: Does one person not arouse pleasure in another?
“That can’t be said.”
Does one person arouse pleasure in another?
“Yes.”

original: Paro parassa attano sukhaṁ anuppadeti, aññesaṁ sukhaṁ anuppadeti, tassa sukhaṁ anuppadetīti?
analyzed: paraḥ parassa attanaḥ sukham anuppadeti aññesam sukham anuppadeti tassa sukham anuppadeti iti
translated: Does one person arouse pleasure in oneself, in others, or in that person?
“That can’t be said.”

original: paro parassa nevattano, na aññesaṁ, na tassa sukhaṁ anuppadetīti?
analyzed: paraḥ parassa na ivattanaḥ na aññesa na tassa sukham anuppadeti iti
translated: Does one person not arouse pleasure in oneself, in others, or in that person?

original: Āmantā.🔽Hañci paro parassa nevattano, na aññesaṁ, na tassa sukhaṁ anuppadeti, no ca vata re vattabbe—
analyzed: āmantā  hañci paraḥ parassa na ivattano na aññesa na tassa sukham no ca vata re vattabbe
translated: “Yes.”
“If one person does not arouse pleasure in oneself, in others, or in that person, then it’s not correct to say that one person arouses pleasure in another.”
“Does one person arouse pleasure in another?”
“Yes.”

original: Añño aññassa kārako, paraṅkataṁ sukhaṁ dukkhaṁ añño karoti añño paṭisaṁvedetīti?🔽Na hevaṁ vattabbe …pe….
analyzed: aññaḥ aññassa kārako paraṅkatam sukham dukkham aññaḥ karoti aññaḥ paṭisavedeti iti  na ha ivam vattabbe pe
translated: Is one person the doer, and another the experiencer?🔽You say “No.”🔽You say “No.”

analyzed: na vattabba  paraḥ parassa sukham anuppadeti iti
translated: You say “No.”
You say “Yes.”

original: Nanu āyasmā udāyī etadavoca—🔽“bahūnaṁ vata no bhagavā dukkhadhammānaṁ apahattā, bahūnaṁ vata no bhagavā sukhadhammānaṁ
analyzed: nanu āyasmai udāyī etat avoca  bahūnam vata naḥ bhagavā dukkha dhammānam apahattā bahūnam vata naḥ bhagavā sukha dhammānaḥ
translated: Then the venerable Udāyī said this:🔽“The Blessed One has removed many things that are liable to suffering,🔽the Blessed One has brought us many things that are liable to happiness,

original: upahattā, bahūnaṁ vata no bhagavā akusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ apahattā, bahūnaṁ vata no
analyzed: upahattā bahūnam vata naḥ bhagavā akusalānam dhammānam apahattā bahūnam vata naḥ
translated: the Blessed One has removed many unwholesome things,
the Blessed One has brought us many wholesome things.”
“Is there such a discourse?”
“Yes.”

original: Tena hi paro parassa sukhaṁ anuppadetīti.
analyzed: tena hi paraḥ parassa sukham anuppadeti iti
translated: “Then one person does bring happiness to another.”
The Discussion of the Bringing about of Happiness is finished.
